column4: My friend phoned me... He ordered a CD with a couple of distros on it... for his new Acer Aspire notebook.  He wants to mount the DVD on another machine with a DVDROM Drive, and then install individual applications via a network cable onto the Aspire which has no removable drives.  Problem is that the whole distribution is in ons large file /casper/filesystem.squashfs  Any idea how he can access individual packages out of this one l
There aren't any packages in there. It contains the fs of the live session, and when you install, it copies files from it directly, it doesn't install packages.
The alternative install disc contains packages though, since it has room for it without a live session.
That command doesn't look valid, but what filesystem is on the 60G?
What I need is what I imagine would be a fstab file used for mounting via the filemanager.
The mount cannot change ownership or permissions of an ext4 filesystem. You really do need to chown it. Though once you have chowned it, it'll be permanently so
but what is other users log in under their own accounts?
They'll likely have no access since it's owned by you
Exactly... so how do I get it to mount like the others that work fine?
If you want others to have access, create a group, add them and yourself as members of that group, give the group the proper permissions for the files on that filesystem
I hear you, but the other hard disk mounts just fine per user.
And what filesystem does that one have?
Then it probably has laxer permissions set
as in "relaxed", less strict. Anyway, I recommend you read http://mywiki.wooledge.org/Permissions
